meanings.definition: To present information in a way that is intended to provoke interest or excitement.
meanings.sent1: The news article tried to sensationalise the story to grab readers' attention.
meanings.sent2: Some newspapers sensationalise stories to sell more copies.
meanings.sent3: The movie director decided to sensationalise the plot by adding unexpected twists.
meanings.sent4: Her speech sensationalised the importance of environmental conservation.
meanings.sent5: The marketing team wanted to sensationalise the product launch to attract a larger audience.

meanings.definition: To exaggerate or distort information in order to make it more exciting or shocking.
meanings.sent1: The tabloid magazine tends to sensationalise celebrity gossip.
meanings.sent2: Some TV shows sensationalise events to increase viewership.
meanings.sent3: The comedian joked that his friend tends to sensationalise his fishing stories.
meanings.sent4: Her paintings sensationalise reality by adding vibrant colors.
meanings.sent5: The author chose to sensationalise the characters in the novel to create more drama.
